importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the White House officially began demolishing part of the East Wing to construct Trump's ballroom, marking a pivotal moment in the construction timeline.
When President Trump first announced the ballroom project, stating it would not interfere with the mansion and emphasizing his vision for a grander space.
When site preparation, including clearing trees on the south grounds, began, signaling early stages of major construction.
The projected completion date of the ballroom before the end of President Trump’s term, indicating the timeline for completion and public use.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The construction period from the start of demolition to the projected completion of the ballroom, spanning over three years with a specific end date tied to Trump’s presidential term.

keyTakeAways: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing in October 2025 to build a $250 million ballroom for President Trump.
The project lacks approval from the National Capital Planning Commission, which typically oversees major renovations to federal buildings.
The East Wing, built in 1902 and renovated in 1942, houses key offices including those of the first lady and will be temporarily relocated during construction.
Trump claims the new ballroom will accommodate 999 people, up from 650 originally announced, and insists it will not interfere with the existing White House structure.
The project is privately funded, with Trump stating that 'zero cost to the American taxpayer,' and donations from wealthy business executives and companies like Carrier Global Corp. are being used.
Carrier Global Corp. has agreed to donate an energy-efficient HVAC system for the ballroom, highlighting private sector involvement in government construction.
The White House has not disclosed full details of donors, and the National Capital Planning Commission remains inactive due to a government shutdown.
The ballroom will be the largest structural change to the White House since the 1948 addition of the Truman Balcony.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The White House began demolishing part of the East Wing in October 2025 to construct a $250 million, 90,000-square-foot glass-walled ballroom for President Donald Trump, despite lacking approval from the National Capital Planning Commission. The project, which was initially announced in July, will allow the ballroom to accommodate up to 999 people, significantly expanding from the original 650-seat capacity. While Trump claims the construction will cost nothing to taxpayers and is privately funded through donations from wealthy individuals and companies like Carrier Global Corp., which has donated an HVAC system, the White House has not disclosed full donor information. The East Wing, built in 1902 and housing key offices including those of the first lady, will be temporarily relocated during construction. The project is the largest structural change to the White House since 1948 and has sparked debate over federal oversight, historical preservation, and executive authority in major renovations.
title: The White House Starts Demolishing Part of the East Wing to Build Trump's Ballroom
